Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Learning from nature - Marine educational games that assess scientific knowledge transfer through game play
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase 1 project will create an engaging online learning game using venomous marine snails as a conduit to explore scientific issues in nature through creative problem solving. The USA is currently ranked 52nd in the world in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) education. This is detrimental intellectually and economically to the future of American society. Recent studies have indicated it is not what we teach, but how we teach that enhances student-learning abilities, particularly as it pertains to STEM. A strong case is being made for using learning games to convey educational content. This project is driven by the research objectives to understand how children learn specific science content and why certain game elements are better suited to convey scientific material. The outcome of this project will be a propriety digital learning game including a unique parent/player assessment tool used to measure novel STEM content during game playing and extending opportunities for learners to engage in ongoing scientific research ("citizen science"). Commercialization of the products created in this project will transform scientific discoveries in predatory marine snail research for social and economic benefit to meet the NSF's mission of supporting education initiatives that improve the lives of U.S. Citizens, and generate income for tax revenue and jobs via the employment of software designers, educators and scientists.

This project will build proprietary assessment tools into online games that continuously engage users in the scientific process of discovery and application of science learning using a novel player/parent data aggregator dashboard. Our inventive two-sided player/parent dashboard will allow players to measure their progress and attain unique, educational rewards such as unlocking new game components, and identifying local citizen science projects to enhance their STEM learning. The goal of this project is to disrupt the status quo of STEM learning and address STEM learning market needs by combining gameplay, content learning, and assessment tools to develop high-quality, creative, science learning games. A three-component Play-Break-Fix strategy will be used to design and develop all games: 1. Iterative prototyping to generate novel ideas and integrate any existing content. 2. Repetitive evaluation to test the usability of demos and the initial feasibility of the learning games created and parent/player dashboard concept. 3. Commercialization testing of the products from this project that are the best of the build and analyze model. The parent/player assessment dashboard developed in this project will provide a template for furthering parental engagement with children's learning to significantly improve STEM knowledge and will engage players in citizen science experiences that will strengthen their connection to STEM learning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Summary: Killer Snails: Learning with a Bite

Overview  

Killer Snails creates transformative science learning games that harness extreme creatures in nature to teach complex scientific concepts that spark scientific inquiry and discovery amongst students in K-12 classrooms. Team Killer Snails (KS) had three objectives during our NSF-Phase I award to: (1) Develop an interactive digital extension to our inaugural hands-on learning game “Killer Snails: Assassins of the Sea,” (2) Validate our customer desire for a proprietary dual-facing player/teacher or player/parent formative assessment dashboard prototype, and (3) Identify key partners to propel critical milestones for commercialization. We significantly advanced these objectives and as a result KS received accolades from educational and gaming communities nationwide such as New York City Public Schools, Somers Independent School District, Origins Game Fair and Board Game Geek, validating our business plan and inaugural products.

The KS team is made up of an active marine biochemist, educational psychologist, Columbia-trained MBA, game developer, and game designer. We hold a unique market niche by combining our expertise in scientific investigation of extreme marine creatures and educational assessment which allows us to create learning experiences that educate and inspire a new generation of science changemakers. The team brings a collective 25 years of teaching experience to our product development. 

To identify our appropriate customer segments and value propositions to drive the development of our beta digital learning game prototype we conducted: i) 150+ interviews, ii) participated in ideation workshops, and iii) conducted several play-break-fix game play session with both the physical and beta digital versions of our Assassins of the Sea educational card game. As a result of these efforts we identified middle school educators/administrators as our key customer segment and attended the International Society of Technology in Education (ISTE) conference where more than 100 teachers/school administrators played both our card and beta digital prototype with assessment dashboard wireframes. The response has been overwhelmingly enthusiastic, resulting in three separate school districts in New York and California agreeing to pilot-test an advanced version of the Assassins of the Sea 2.0 digital learning game. Team KS attended Origins Game Fair and GenCon where over 500 attendees enjoyed playing our game. These activities and the responses from our customer segment successfully demonstrate the feasibility of our innovation and its ability to address the value proposition of teachers by finding ways to align with new Next Generation Science Standards and International Baccalaureate standards and to capture the attention of budding STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) learners.

Intellectual Merit  

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project aimed to demonstrate the technical feasibility of the proposed innovation and thereby bring our innovative, educational game closer to commercialization. The marine science featured in this game is cutting-edge research conducted by a practicing, award-winning scientist. The assessment dashboard is being designed by a practicing assessment and educational psychologist. Our game designers have created dozens of games in the web, mobile, Facebook, massive-multiplayer, board, card, and real-world spaces.

During our customer discovery and validation phases, Killer Snails interviewed and demonstrated beta versions of our dashboard with teachers and school administrators. During these conversations, teachers were particularly excited to learn how our dashboard would provide scaffolded questions specific to player actions during game play. The desire for high quality, NGSS-aligned curriculum supplements translates into a highly viable customer base for KS products. Specifically, the commercial application of KS products is to sell to middle schools educators on a national and international level to address the global need of finding effective tools for teaching STEM and engaging learners in STEM fields. 

Broader/Commercial Impact

The broader impacts of KS products is the creation of resources that will improve STEM education nationally and internationally. We aim to develop transformative digital and virtual games that inspire players to engage in scientific discovery and become critical thinkers about biodiversity and biomedical applications. During Phase I, Killer Snails playtested our learning games at a variety of local and national events including Microsoft Playcrafting, Playcrafting Annual Demo Day, semi-annual Demo Day at the New York Media Center, Rockefeller Science Saturdays, The Feminist Press STEMinism conference, and the New York Annual World Science Festival. In total, we playtested Killer Snails: Assassins of the Sea card game with over 600 people who provided invaluable feedback on the mechanics of gameplay, and highlighted the underlying learning progression during game play which was mapped on to the formative assessment dashboard component of the digital prototype. These events to share KS products with a large lay audience were prime opportunities to introduce the KS brand, build brand recognition and help us identify future KS products to meet the customer base and market needs.
